ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Pseudohypoacusis (Functional Hearing Loss)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Confirmed by inconsistencies between severe subjective hearing loss and normal objective measures (reflexes, OAEs, ABR), positive Stenger, and resolution of hearing loss upon re-test after counseling.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Vestibular Migraine
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Supported by history of spontaneous vertigo episodes lasting hours to days, accompanied by headache, nausea, and photophobia.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Visual Motion Sensitivity
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Patient reports unsteadiness provoked by walking in grocery store aisles and moving objects; confirmed by symptoms during optokinetics testing.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Perilymphatic Fistula
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Considered due to trauma history and reported symptoms, but ruled out by negative fistula tests, lack of exertion-induced symptoms, and normal tympanometry.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Superior Canal Dehiscence
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: CT showed thinning of the superior canal roof, but VEMPs were absent (not enhanced) and the air-bone gap was too large to be explained solely by SCD.

ordered_list.rationale_short: To evaluate for structural pathology given history of trauma and surgeries.
To cross-check middle ear status and hearing sensitivity.
Objective assessment of outer hair cell function to investigate inconsistencies.
Threshold estimation to rule out retrocochlear pathology and confirm sensitivity.
Repeat testing after counseling to establish true organic thresholds.
Repeat testing to confirm consistency with new thresholds.
Comprehensive battery (VNG, Rotary Chair, VEMPs, Posturography) to evaluate disequilibrium.
To evaluate middle ear status and check for fistula.
To evaluate for anxiety, depression, or other contributors to functional symptoms.
To screen for anxiety and depression as part of the vestibular evaluation.
To assess peripheral vestibular function (lateral semicircular canals).

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Radiology studies revealed thinning of the superior canal roof but no definite dehiscence, ruling out obvious structural causes for the reported severity of symptoms.

tests.name: CT scan of temporal bones
tests.result_summary: Thinning of the roof of the superior canal on the right ear but no definite areas of focal bone dehiscence; temporal bones otherwise unremarkable.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial behavioral testing suggested severe conductive hearing loss, but this was contradicted by normal acoustic reflexes, OAEs, and ABR thresholds. Following counseling on these inconsistencies, repeat behavioral testing revealed normal hearing sensitivity. Vestibular testing was largely normal, with absent right VEMPs likely due to prior surgeries.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Initial: Right ear severe conductive loss (80-90 dB HL) with 65-75 dB air-bone gaps; Left ear normal. Positive Stenger.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Initial: Right WRS 85% at 90 dB HL (10 dB SL), excellent score at low sensation level inconsistent with severe loss.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds bilaterally (85-95 dB HL), contradicting the severe conductive loss.

tests.name: Distortion-product otoacoustic emissions (DPOAEs)
tests.result_summary: Present 2000-4000 Hz in right ear, indicating normal outer hair cell function.

tests.name: Auditory Brainstem Response (ABR)
tests.result_summary: Wave V present at 20 dB nHL with appropriate latencies, indicating normal sensitivity 1000-4000 Hz.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Follow-up: Right ear thresholds 0-15 dB HL (250-8000 Hz) with slight 10 dB air-bone gap at low frequencies.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: Follow-up: SRT 10 dB HL, WRS 100% at 50 dB HL.

tests.name: Vestibular Evaluation
tests.result_summary: VNG, Rotary Chair, and Posturography normal. Bithermal caloric normal, Dixâ€‘Hallpike/roll negative, pursuit/saccades normal, Valsalva negative, platform pressure normal. VEMPs normal left, absent right (likely secondary to middle ear surgeries).

tests.name: Tympanometry
tests.result_summary: Normal middle ear pressure and compliance bilaterally; multiple-peaked tympanogram in the right ear.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Multidisciplinary consults ruled out active otologic pathology and major psychiatric disorders. The evaluation pointed towards vestibular migraine and visual motion sensitivity as the primary causes of disequilibrium.

tests.name: Otologic Exam
tests.result_summary: Scarring and tympanosclerosis on TM; no spontaneous nystagmus; no active fistula.

tests.name: Psychiatric Consult
tests.result_summary: MINI showed no significant depression or anxiety; noted possibility of vestibular migraine.

tests.name: Physical Therapy Evaluation
tests.result_summary: Umbrella optokinetics testing induced 'warm' feeling similar to grocery store symptoms; VOR and gait normal.

proposed_items: Physical therapy for visual motion sensitivity
counseling_actions: Explanation of inconsistencies between subjective and objective test results
Reassurance regarding normal hearing sensitivity and inner ear function
Education on visual motion sensitivity and its triggers (e.g., grocery aisles)
Discussion of vestibular migraine as a potential cause of spontaneous vertigo

escalation.rationale_short: For habituation therapy to address visual motion sensitivity and improve tolerance to visual stimuli.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor motion-provoked symptoms and adherence to habituation exercises.

expected_outcome: The primary outcome for this patient is to remain in contact with physical therapy should his motion-provoked symptoms become more severe.
